source: FDA Orthopedic Device Guidance + AAOS Clinical Outcomes + ISO 14243/14242

primary_efficacy.name: Harris Hip Score (HHS)
primary_efficacy.definition: Composite score (0-100) assessing pain, function, range of motion, and absence of deformity in hip arthroplasty patients
primary_efficacy.measurement_timepoint: Baseline (pre-op), 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months, annually to 10 years
primary_efficacy.success_criteria: Mean HHS ≥80 at 12 months (excellent outcome); improvement ≥20 points from baseline (clinically meaningful)
primary_efficacy.source: Harris WH. J Bone Joint Surg Am 1969;51:737-755
primary_efficacy.clinical_significance: Most widely used hip outcome score; >80 = excellent, 70-80 = good, 60-70 = fair, <60 = poor
primary_efficacy.typical_analysis: Mean change from baseline with paired t-test; responder analysis (≥20 point improvement)
primary_efficacy.regulatory_notes: FDA accepts HHS as primary efficacy endpoint for THA devices; 10-year data required for PMA

primary_efficacy.name: WOMAC (Western Ontario McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index)
primary_efficacy.definition: 24-item questionnaire assessing pain (5 items), stiffness (2 items), physical function (17 items) on Likert scale
primary_efficacy.measurement_timepoint: Baseline, 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months, annually
primary_efficacy.success_criteria: ≥50% reduction in total WOMAC score from baseline at 12 months
primary_efficacy.clinical_significance: Gold standard for knee and hip OA; lower score = better outcome; responsive to change
primary_efficacy.typical_analysis: Percentage change from baseline; minimal clinically important difference (MCID) = 12% reduction
primary_efficacy.regulatory_notes: FDA accepts WOMAC for TKA devices; normalized to 0-100 scale for reporting

primary_efficacy.name: Range of Motion (ROM)
primary_efficacy.definition: Active and passive joint range measured with goniometer (degrees): Hip (flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, rotation), Knee (flexion, extension)
primary_efficacy.measurement_timepoint: Baseline, 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months, annually
primary_efficacy.success_criteria: Knee flexion ≥110° at 12 months; Hip flexion ≥90° at 12 months
primary_efficacy.clinical_significance: Functional ROM required for activities of daily living: knee 110° (stairs), hip 90° (sitting)
primary_efficacy.typical_analysis: Mean ± SD with change from baseline; proportion achieving functional thresholds
primary_efficacy.regulatory_notes: Objective measure to supplement patient-reported outcomes

primary_efficacy.name: Revision Rate (Implant Survival)
primary_efficacy.definition: Proportion of implants requiring surgical removal or replacement for any reason (aseptic loosening, infection, fracture, instability)
primary_efficacy.success_criteria: Survival ≥95% at 10 years for primary THA/TKA (per registry data)
primary_efficacy.source: National Joint Registry (UK), AJRR (US), Australian Registry
primary_efficacy.clinical_significance: Gold standard for long-term implant performance; revision is objective, unambiguous endpoint
primary_efficacy.typical_analysis: Kaplan-Meier survival analysis with 95% CI; Cox proportional hazards for risk factors
primary_efficacy.regulatory_notes: FDA requires minimum 2-year data for 510(k), 5-10 year data for PMA; competitive to registry benchmarks

primary_efficacy.name: Radiographic Loosening
primary_efficacy.definition: Presence of progressive radiolucent lines (>2mm), component migration (>2mm subsidence or >5° change in angle), or cement mantle fracture
primary_efficacy.measurement_timepoint: 6 weeks (baseline), 6 months, 12 months, annually to 10 years
primary_efficacy.success_criteria: Radiographic loosening <5% at 2 years, <10% at 5 years
primary_efficacy.source: Gruen zones (hip stem), Knee Society radiographic criteria
primary_efficacy.clinical_significance: Surrogate endpoint for future revision; may precede clinical symptoms by years
primary_efficacy.typical_analysis: Proportion with loosening at each timepoint; radiographic review by independent assessors
primary_efficacy.regulatory_notes: AP and lateral radiographs required; independent blinded review by 2+ radiologists; inter-observer agreement (kappa >0.6)

primary_efficacy.name: Oswestry Disability Index (ODI)
primary_efficacy.definition: 10-item questionnaire (0-100 scale) assessing back pain disability: pain intensity, personal care, lifting, walking, sitting, standing, sleeping, social life, travel, employment
primary_efficacy.measurement_timepoint: Baseline, 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months, 24 months
primary_efficacy.success_criteria: ≥15 point improvement from baseline at 12 months (MCID)
primary_efficacy.clinical_significance: Most widely used spine disability measure; 0-20% = minimal, 21-40% = moderate, 41-60% = severe, 61-80% = crippled, 81-100% = bedbound
primary_efficacy.typical_analysis: Mean change from baseline; responder analysis (≥15 point improvement = success)
primary_efficacy.regulatory_notes: FDA accepts ODI as primary endpoint for lumbar fusion devices; typically paired with radiographic fusion assessment

primary_efficacy.name: Fusion Success (Radiographic and CT)
primary_efficacy.definition: Bridging bone across fusion site with <5° angular motion on flexion-extension radiographs OR continuous trabecular bone on CT (Lenke Grade A or B)
primary_efficacy.success_criteria: Fusion rate ≥75% at 24 months for single-level lumbar fusion
primary_efficacy.source: Lenke classification for CT fusion grading; FDA spine guidance
primary_efficacy.clinical_significance: Anatomic endpoint; fusion does not always correlate with clinical improvement, but non-union correlates with poor outcomes
primary_efficacy.typical_analysis: Proportion achieving fusion with exact 95% CI; independent assessment by 2+ radiologists
primary_efficacy.regulatory_notes: FDA requires both radiographic and CT assessment; fine-cut CT (1-2mm slices) with multiplanar reconstruction; blinded independent review

primary_efficacy.name: Fracture Healing (Union)
primary_efficacy.definition: Bridging callus on ≥3 cortices (AP and lateral radiographs) AND absence of pain/motion at fracture site
primary_efficacy.success_criteria: Union rate ≥90% at 6 months for closed femoral shaft fractures; ≥85% for open fractures
primary_efficacy.clinical_significance: Primary endpoint for trauma fixation devices; delayed union (>6 months) or non-union (>9 months) requires intervention
primary_efficacy.typical_analysis: Proportion achieving union; time-to-union Kaplan-Meier analysis
primary_efficacy.regulatory_notes: Independent radiographic review required; clinical exam to confirm absence of motion/pain at fracture site

primary_safety.name: Infection (Superficial and Deep)
primary_safety.definition: Superficial: incision site infection within 30 days. Deep: Periprosthetic joint infection (PJI) requiring antibiotics ± revision surgery
primary_safety.success_criteria: Superficial infection <2%, deep PJI <1% at 2 years for primary THA/TKA
primary_safety.clinical_significance: Deep PJI is catastrophic complication often requiring implant removal, antibiotic spacer, and 2-stage revision
primary_safety.typical_analysis: Kaplan-Meier cumulative incidence with competing risk for death or revision for other causes
primary_safety.regulatory_notes: Must distinguish superficial from deep infection; microbiologic culture and ESR/CRP required for deep infection diagnosis

primary_safety.name: Dislocation (Hip)
primary_safety.definition: Separation of femoral head from acetabular component requiring closed or open reduction
primary_safety.success_criteria: Dislocation rate <3% at 2 years for primary THA
primary_safety.clinical_significance: Leading cause of early revision; recurrent dislocation (≥2 events) often requires revision to constrained liner or dual-mobility
primary_safety.typical_analysis: Kaplan-Meier time-to-first-dislocation; recurrent dislocation rate (≥2 events)
primary_safety.regulatory_notes: Report first dislocation and recurrent dislocations separately; document reduction method (closed vs. open)

primary_safety.name: Periprosthetic Fracture
primary_safety.definition: Fracture of bone adjacent to or involving the implant, classified by Vancouver (hip), Rorabeck (knee), or similar systems
primary_safety.clinical_significance: Serious complication often requiring revision surgery; risk factors include osteoporosis, trauma, osteolysis
primary_safety.typical_analysis: Cumulative incidence with competing risks; classification of fracture type and treatment
primary_safety.regulatory_notes: Distinguish intraoperative from postoperative fractures; report treatment (ORIF vs. revision)

primary_safety.name: Nerve Injury
primary_safety.definition: New postoperative sensory or motor deficit in anatomically relevant nerve distribution (sciatic, femoral, peroneal, tibial)
primary_safety.source: Clinical examination, EMG/NCS if persistent >6 weeks
primary_safety.clinical_significance: Most nerve injuries are transient (neuropraxia) and resolve within 3-6 months; permanent injury is disabling
primary_safety.typical_analysis: Proportion with nerve injury; classification as transient (<3 months), prolonged (3-12 months), or permanent (>12 months)
primary_safety.regulatory_notes: Independent neurologist evaluation for persistent deficits; EMG/NCS at 6 weeks and 3 months if no improvement

primary_safety.name: Venous Thromboembolism (VTE)
primary_safety.definition: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) confirmed by duplex ultrasound OR pulmonary embolism (PE) confirmed by CT angiography
primary_safety.success_criteria: Symptomatic VTE <2% at 90 days with chemoprophylaxis
primary_safety.source: ACCP anticoagulation guidelines for orthopedic surgery
primary_safety.clinical_significance: Major cause of morbidity/mortality post-THA/TKA; requires anticoagulation for 3-6 months
primary_safety.typical_analysis: Cumulative incidence; distinguish DVT from PE; fatal PE rate
primary_safety.regulatory_notes: Report chemoprophylaxis regimen (LMWH, warfarin, DOAC, aspirin); objective testing required for diagnosis

primary_safety.name: Osteolysis
primary_safety.definition: Progressive bone resorption (radiolucency) >2mm adjacent to implant, attributed to wear debris-induced inflammatory response
primary_safety.measurement_timepoint: Annually starting at 2 years through 10+ years
primary_safety.source: Radiographic assessment per Gruen zones (hip), AAOS criteria (knee)
primary_safety.clinical_significance: Precursor to aseptic loosening and revision; polyethylene wear debris is primary etiology
primary_safety.typical_analysis: Cumulative incidence over time; location and volume quantification if CT performed
primary_safety.regulatory_notes: Independent blinded radiographic review; correlation with wear measurements from explant analysis if revision performed

primary_safety.name: Subsidence (Spinal Implants)
primary_safety.definition: Settling of interbody cage into adjacent vertebral endplate, measured as >3mm loss of disc height on lateral radiograph
primary_safety.source: Marchi et al. J Neurosurg Spine 2013;19:110-8
primary_safety.clinical_significance: May lead to loss of lordosis, foraminal stenosis, non-union; risk factors include osteoporosis, oversized cage
primary_safety.typical_analysis: Mean subsidence with SD; proportion with clinically significant subsidence (>3mm or >5mm thresholds)
primary_safety.regulatory_notes: Standing lateral radiographs required for accurate measurement; independent radiographic review

secondary_endpoints.name: EQ-5D (EuroQol 5-Dimension)
secondary_endpoints.definition: Generic health status measure (5 dimensions: mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/discomfort, anxiety/depression) with utility score 0-1
secondary_endpoints.source: EuroQol Group; EQ-5D-5L version (5 levels per dimension)
secondary_endpoints.clinical_significance: Allows cost-effectiveness analysis (QALY); generic measure permits comparison across disease states
secondary_endpoints.typical_analysis: Mean change in utility score; QALY calculation for economic evaluation
secondary_endpoints.regulatory_notes: FDA does not typically require but useful for CMS coverage decisions and international submissions

secondary_endpoints.name: Oxford Hip/Knee Score
secondary_endpoints.definition: 12-item joint-specific outcome measure (0-48 scale, higher = better); Oxford Hip Score for THA, Oxford Knee Score for TKA
secondary_endpoints.success_criteria: Mean score ≥35 at 12 months (good outcome); improvement ≥8 points from baseline (MCID)
secondary_endpoints.source: Dawson J. J Bone Joint Surg Br 1996;78:185-90 (hip), 1998;80:63-9 (knee)
secondary_endpoints.clinical_significance: Simpler than HHS/KSS; patient-reported; widely used in UK/Europe
secondary_endpoints.typical_analysis: Mean score and change from baseline; responder analysis (≥8 point improvement)
secondary_endpoints.regulatory_notes: Less commonly used than HHS/WOMAC in FDA submissions but gaining acceptance

secondary_endpoints.name: Polyethylene Wear Rate
secondary_endpoints.definition: Linear wear (mm/year) or volumetric wear (mm³/year) measured from serial radiographs using validated software (e.g., PolyWare, EBRA)
secondary_endpoints.success_criteria: Linear wear <0.1 mm/year for highly cross-linked polyethylene (HXLPE)
secondary_endpoints.source: ISO 14242 (knee wear testing), ISO 14243 (hip wear testing); radiographic measurement per Dorr et al.
secondary_endpoints.clinical_significance: Surrogate for long-term osteolysis risk; conventional PE ~0.2 mm/yr, HXLPE ~0.05 mm/yr
secondary_endpoints.typical_analysis: Linear regression of head penetration over time; wear rate with 95% CI
secondary_endpoints.regulatory_notes: Requires annual radiographs with standardized technique; specialized software and trained readers; correlate with explant wear analysis if available

secondary_endpoints.name: Patient Satisfaction
secondary_endpoints.definition: Single-item or multi-item questionnaire assessing satisfaction with surgery outcome (e.g., 5-point Likert: very satisfied to very dissatisfied)
secondary_endpoints.success_criteria: ≥80% very satisfied or satisfied at 12 months
secondary_endpoints.source: Various validated instruments (e.g., HSS Hip Replacement Expectations Survey)
secondary_endpoints.clinical_significance: Correlates imperfectly with objective outcomes; influenced by expectations and psychological factors
secondary_endpoints.typical_analysis: Proportion satisfied/very satisfied; correlation with HHS/WOMAC scores
secondary_endpoints.regulatory_notes: Not typically primary endpoint but useful patient-centered outcome; pre/post expectations influence satisfaction

secondary_endpoints.name: Return to Work/Activities
secondary_endpoints.definition: Time to return to previous employment or recreational activities; proportion returning by 6 months and 12 months
secondary_endpoints.success_criteria: ≥70% return to work by 6 months (age <65 and employed pre-injury)
secondary_endpoints.clinical_significance: Functional outcome relevant to younger, active patients; influenced by job demands and socioeconomic factors
secondary_endpoints.typical_analysis: Time-to-return Kaplan-Meier analysis; proportion returning by timepoint
secondary_endpoints.regulatory_notes: Confounded by non-device factors (workers' compensation, disability claims); useful secondary endpoint for sports medicine devices

notes.registry_benchmarks: Compare outcomes to national registry data (AJRR, UK NJR, Australian Registry) for context; 95% survival at 10 years is benchmark for THA/TKA
notes.follow_up_duration: Minimum 2 years for 510(k); 5-10 years for PMA; lifetime surveillance for registries
notes.radiographic_standards: Standardized AP and lateral radiographs; weight-bearing for lower extremity; independent blinded review by 2+ assessors; inter-observer agreement (kappa >0.6)
notes.patient_reported_outcomes: PROMIS (Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System) increasingly used as alternative to legacy scores; computerized adaptive testing reduces burden
notes.minimal_clinically_important_difference: HHS ≥20 points, WOMAC ≥12%, ODI ≥15 points, Oxford ≥8 points; use for responder analyses
notes.statistical_considerations: Sample size based on primary endpoint non-inferiority to predicate; adjust for multiple comparisons if multiple primary endpoints; intention-to-treat analysis for clinical outcomes; per-protocol for radiographic outcomes
